name: The Family & Youth Institute
mission: Redefining the narrative on Muslim mental health and well-being and championing a world where individuals, families, and communities are empowered and flourishing.
theoryOfChange: The Family & Youth Institute explicitly states 'the fyi's theory of change' within their 'Research' section. Their approach is described as a community-based participatory research model that ensures community voices and experiences drive their research. This involves partnering with communities to pinpoint priorities, exploring research questions, identifying wellness needs, and addressing concerns within faith and cultural contexts. They engage and integrate community voices throughout the research process, incorporate community perspectives on data, identify practical solutions, and share the benefits. Their mission is to strengthen and empower individuals, families, and communities through research and education, working to shift narratives and promote mental health and well-being.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://thefyi.org/zakat (Source: https://thefyi.org/zakat)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Limited match due to weaker results and/or higher uncertainty; review methodology details before deciding.

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Humanitarian service (+2)
components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

alignment.rationale: Alignment 29/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, advocacy cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data available for cost-per-beneficiary scoring; good program ratio (≥75%) suggests reasonable delivery
components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: If reserves are above policy target, document why and publish triggers for planned deployment.

components.evidence: Board governance: baseline (2 members, emerging org)
components.name: Governance

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 2 members

score_details.score_summary: THE FAMILY AND YOUTH INSTITUTE shows strong impact and good alignment, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://thefyi.org/zakat (Source: https://thefyi.org/zakat)

all_citations.claim: The organization reported a program expense ratio of 83.6%, working capital of 23.6 months, and fundraising efficiency of $0.09 per $1 raised.
The FYI reported total revenue of $850,837 and operates programs including Mental Health Research and the Aging with Dignity Project.
The organization provides various donation options and giving methods for supporters.
The FYI is zakat-eligible and provides details on its zakat policy and asnaf categories.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The FYI earns a moderate overall score due to its strong financial efficiency and specialized focus on mental health, though its total score is tempered by low data confidence and a capacity-building impact model.
areas_for_improvement: Low data confidence score suggests a need for more transparent third-party impact verification
Limited external performance ratings from major charity evaluators

dimension_explanations.alignment: The FYI shows medium donor fit as it addresses urgent community needs through its Mental Health Research and Aging with Dignity projects [2]. It offers specific religious alignment for Muslim donors by maintaining a dedicated zakat policy [4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates high financial health with a program expense ratio of 83.6% and 23.6 months of working capital [1][2]. While its impact is categorized as capacity building rather than direct service delivery, it maintains efficient operations with a fundraising cost of only $0.09 per $1 raised [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Family and Youth Institute (The FYI) is a research and education organization dedicated to strengthening individuals and families through evidence-based mental health and development programs.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 83.6% ensures the majority of funds support direct services
Strong fundraising efficiency of $0.09 per $1 raised
Significant working capital of 23.6 months providing long-term financial stability
Clear zakat eligibility policy and asnaf category alignment
baseline_narrative.summary: The FYI reported a total revenue of $850,837 and focuses on community empowerment through research-driven initiatives [1][2]. The organization is recognized as zakat-eligible, allowing donors to contribute toward programs that support mental health and youth development within the community [4].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The FYI earns a moderate overall score due to its strong financial efficiency and specialized focus on mental health, though its total score is tempered by low data confidence and a capacity-building impact model.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization currently operates with only <cite id="2">2 board members</cite>, which is below best-practice standards for independent oversight.
The charity currently meets <cite id="1">0 of 20 BBB standards</cite>, indicating significant room for improvement in formal governance and transparency policies.

bbb_assessment.summary: Meets 0 of 20 BBB Wise Giving Alliance Standards for Charity Accountability

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization maintains strong financial health despite governance limitations.
case_against.summary: The primary concerns revolve around governance and transparency, specifically the <cite id="2">small board size</cite> and lack of external accreditation.

data_gaps: Not fully rated by Charity Navigator
confidence.notes: Data confidence is low due to limited transparency and lack of external evaluations.

known_gaps: Not fully rated by Charity Navigator

alignment.explanation: The charity is a strong fit for donors interested in mental health advocacy and research, offering <cite id="4">zakat-eligible</cite> giving options under the <cite id="4">fisabilillah category</cite>.
alignment.improvement: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.

credibility.explanation: Donors should note that data confidence is low due to limited transparency. The organization has a very small board of <cite id="2">2 board members</cite> and currently meets <cite id="1">0 of 20 BBB standards</cite>, indicating limited formal oversight structures.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the charity should expand its board to at least five independent members and work toward meeting BBB Wise Giving Alliance standards.

impact.explanation: The organization demonstrates excellent financial efficiency, with an <cite id="2">83.6% program expense ratio</cite> and a highly efficient <cite id="1">fundraising efficiency of $0.09 per $1 raised</cite>.
impact.improvement: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Documented theory of change but limited outcome data

rich_narrative.headline: The Family and Youth Institute (The FYI) is a research and education organization dedicated to strengthening individuals and families through evidence-based mental health and development programs.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to invest in long-term capacity building, research, and educational resources for Muslim mental health and youth development.
donor_motivations: Value research and evidence-based approaches to community issues
Want to support mental health awareness in the Muslim community
Prefer funding systemic capacity building over immediate relief
giving_considerations: Impact is indirect (research/education) rather than direct clinical care
Organization has limited formal governance structures
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking immediate humanitarian relief or direct clinical mental health services.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: The organization has a documented theory of change and verified evidence of outcomes, but lacks rigorous third-party impact evaluations.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: Strengthens individuals and families through research and education efforts that promote positive youth development.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: For research organizations, evidence of how their publications and educational materials translate into community behavior change is crucial for understanding true impact.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: The organization has significant reserves but can scale its research output with additional funding.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Focuses heavily on capacity building and research rather than direct clinical services.
peer_comparison.peer_group: Muslim mental health and research organizations

strengths.detail: The organization maintains an excellent <cite id="2">program expense ratio of 83.6%</cite>, ensuring the vast majority of funding supports research and education.
The FYI demonstrates strong <cite id="1">fundraising efficiency of $0.09 per $1 raised</cite>, meaning very little is spent on acquiring donations.
The organization is <cite id="4">zakat-eligible</cite> and clearly designates funds for the <cite id="4">fisabilillah category</cite>.

strengths_deep_dive: The FYI's financial model shows strong operational efficiency for a research institute. With <cite id="2">$850,837 in total revenue</cite>, the organization manages to direct <cite id="2">83.6% to program expenses</cite>. Their <cite id="1">fundraising efficiency of $0.09 per $1 raised</cite> indicates that their donor acquisition strategies are highly cost-effective. Furthermore, the organization has demonstrated steady growth with a <cite id="2">3-year revenue CAGR of 6.1%</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: The Family and Youth Institute (The FYI) is a research and education organization <cite id="2">founded in 2006</cite> that focuses on strengthening individuals and families through evidence-based mental health and youth development programs. The organization reported <cite id="2">$850,837 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 tax year. The FYI operates with high financial efficiency, directing <cite id="2">83.6% to program expenses</cite>. The organization is <cite id="4">zakat-eligible</cite>, accepting funds specifically for the <cite id="4">fisabilillah category</cite>. While the charity demonstrates strong financial metrics, including a <cite id="1">fundraising efficiency of $0.09 per $1 raised</cite>, it currently operates with a very small governance structure of just <cite id="2">2 board members</cite> and meets <cite id="1">0 of 20 BBB standards</cite>.
